sen.j: 武国凝別命（たけくにこりわけのみこと）は、記紀などに伝える古墳時代の皇族。
sen.e: Takekunikoriwakenomikoto was a member of the Imperial Family in the Kofun period (tumulus period), and he was written about in "A Record of Ancient Matters," "Chronicles of Japan," and so on.
Takekunikoriwake no mikoto was a member of the Imperial Family in the Kofun period (tumulus period), and he was written about in "A Record of Ancient Matters," "Chronicles of Japan," and so on.
sen.cmt: 名前のスペースを変更しました。
sen.e: Takekunikoriwake no mikoto was a member of the Imperial Family in the Kofun period (tumulus period), and he was written about in "A Record of Ancient Matters," "Chronicles of Japan," and so on.
He was Takekunikoriwake no oji.

He was Takekunikoriwake no oji.
He was the 12th Prince of Emperor Keiko.

sen.j: 母は阿倍氏木事の女・高田媛。
sen.e: His mother was a daughter of Kikoto ABE, Takatahime.
His mother was a daughter of Kikoto ABE, Takatahime.
His mother was a daughter of Kikoto ABE, Takatahime.

sen.j: 伊予国平定のために派遣され、神野郡（後の新居郡、現在の愛媛県新居浜市・西条市他）に拠点を置いたと伝える。
sen.e: It is said that he was dispatched to Kanno-gun (later Nii County, present Niihama City, Saijo City, etc., Ehime Prefecture) for the subjugation of Iyo Province.
It is said that he was dispatched to Kanno-gun (later Nii County, present Niihama City, Saijo City, etc., Ehime Prefecture) for the subjugation of Iyo Province and used there as his base.
sen.cmt: 訳漏れを補足しました。
sen.e: It is said that he was dispatched to Kanno-gun (later Nii County, present Niihama City, Saijo City, etc., Ehime Prefecture) for the subjugation of Iyo Province and used there as his base.

sen.j: 子孫も地方各地へ広がった。
sen.e: His descendants spread out around Japan.

sen.j: 「別」の子孫が治めたということから別子という地名が生まれた。
sen.e: Because they were descendants (called "shi-son" in Japanese) of Takekunikoriwakenomikoto (also called "Betsu"), the place name "Besshi" was coined.

sen.j: その御霊は拠点地付近に建立された伊曽乃神社に代々篤く奉られている。
sen.e: The spirit of Takekunikoriwakenomikoto has been revered for generations at Isono-jinja Shrine.
The spirit of Takekunikoriwake no mikoto has been revered for generations at Isono-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: なお、円珍（智証大師）の自筆である『円珍俗姓系図』（承和 (日本)年間、園城寺蔵、国宝）は、「景行天皇─武国凝別皇子」に始まる竪系図として貴重である。
sen.e: "Genealogy of secular surname of Enchin" written by Enchin (Chisho Daishi) in his own hand (during the Jowa era, the property of Enjo-ji Temple, a national treasure) is valuable Tatekeizu (a genealogy in which names of parents and those of children are connected with vertical lines) starting with "Emperor Keiko-Takekunikoriwake no oji."

"Genealogy of secular surname of Enchin" written by Enchin (Chisho Daishi) in his own hand (during the Jowa era, the property of Enjo-ji Temple, a national treasure) is valuable Tatekeizu (a genealogy in which names of parents and those of children are connected with vertical lines) starting with "Emperor Keiko-Takekunikoriwake no oji."

sen.j: それによれば、後裔氏族として御村別（みむらわけ、伊曽乃神社社家）・因支首（いなきのおびと）・和気公（わけのきみ）などが伝えられ、円珍自身も和気公の一族であった（俗名を和気公広雄）ことが知られる。
sen.e: According to this genealogy, the descendant clan includes Mimurawake (Isono-jinja Shrine shake (family of Shinto priests serving a shrine on a hereditary basis)), INAGI no Obito and Prince Wake, and Enchin himself is known to have been a member of the family of Prince Wake. (The secular name of Enchin was Hiroo WAKE.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処、円珍の俗名は「和気広雄」と思われます。
sen.e: According to this genealogy, the descendant clans included Mimurawake (Isono-jinja Shrine shake [family of Shinto priests serving a shrine on a hereditary basis]), INAKI no Obito and Wakenokimi, and Enchin himself is known to have been a member of the family of Wakenokimi (The secular name of Enchin was Hiroo WAKENOKIMI).
sen.cmt: ()の中の（）を[ ]に変更。INAGIを INAKIに変更。和気公は一族の姓であると考えられるので、そのように変更しました。
